Both sire and son were repeatedly and, enthusiatically encored. The elder
Brabftm sang several songs with an energy and spirit that completely
electrified his hearers. Miss Stone sang very sweetly, and Heyter did
his part ^> make the evening pass off plaasaoit§r."
We have heard Mr. Braharn, junior, sing in private, and we can add
our own testimony to the accuracy of the above. We also learn that he
will make his first appearance in New York on Monday the 28th instant,
or about t^iat time.—New York Morning Herald, March 19.

Fashionable Lounges.
To the Editor of The TheatricuX Observer,
DKAR Ma. EDITOR,—Just wish to say a word—beg pardon, but will you excuse
me—I ha?e to mention, that I've arranged so as to rub shoulders with my friends
and the fashionable world at one or other of the Grand L»>wigcs about town .—
Monday, visit T H B DIORAMA, Regent's Park.—The Two Pictures now E x hibiting represent The Village of Alyana, in Piedmont, destroyed by an Avalanche,
glinted by M. Bouton ; and The Shrine of the Nativity at Bethlehem, painted by M.
enoux, from a Sketch made on tho spot byD.Roberts, R.A. in 1839, Both Pictures
exhibit various effects of light and shade. They are truly beautiful, and will well
repay a visit to this fashionable lounge. Open from Ten till Five.
Tuesday, paid another visit to the THAMES TUNNELS* it will be shortly closed
to the public, in order to make the necessary preparations for opening it as a
thoroughfare for foot passengers. It is open daily, (Sunday excepted) from 9 in
the morning until dark, and lighted with gas. The Tunnel is now completed,
and is 1,200 feet in length, and the present entrance is on the Surrey side of the
river, close to Rotherhitho Church.
Wednesday, stroll to MAIUMK TUSSAUB'S elegant Exhibition,OoldenCorinthian
Saloon, BnkerStreet, Portman Square.—Just added to her unrivalled collection the
Kmg of Prussia, the Prince of Wales, Commissioner Lin and MB Consort, model led
for tins exhibition byLfimqua, (»f Canton, with the original niagrntkent dresses.&c.
obtained at a great risk \ the only figures of the kind ever seen m Europe. Also just
added, the Princess Royal, in her beautiful cot, with the gorgeous Robes of George
the Fourth designed by himself at a cost of 18,000/L
Afterwards, I mn to b» found udrairifig the beautiful collection of Paintings at
the SOCIETY OF BRITISH ARTISTS, Suffolk Street. Pall Malt, East, which is BOW
open for the season—crowded with fashionables—Admission 13. Intend to join
the CnnverniuUme, subKt'ription \t. Is.
Thursday, pop into the Somerset Gallery, 151, Strand, next door to Somerset HouBe, to see a most wonderful Exhibition, The fnduntrtous >V«a*. They
dnnce, ride, drive u fbur-m-imnd, fight, and in fact do everything in first rate
style, exciting the admiration of ail present. By the bye, this is Signor Bertolotti's
ExhibWon, that has been exhibited for the last eight years.
You may talk of eye snuff, but after having the headache for a year, popped
into Pi1.RHINO'S, 64, Strand, got one of bis superb Beaxers so light lost the headache in a minute—was shewn one of his elegant Velvet Huts, could not resist
buying one of them also, price I Us—wonderful.
In my way from the Theatre, drop into the ftarmtmic Meeting, held at EVANS'S
Grand Hotel, King Street, i'ovent Garden,-quitedelighted with the excellence oi
the singing—commences every e\ening at ten o'clock. Whtsn Mrs. P . is out ol
town, stay a week, and only pay a gninea for bed and breakfast. I'm always to
be found on Saturday, at half-past five, at the Convivial Dinner held here.
Afterwards called "at EiBMnrr's, S7, Holborn Hill, to view his Novel Pen Maker,
by which any one can make a superior Pea in l*ss than one minute I also his improved Ni-edie Threader, to enable Ladies, whose eight is impaired to thread their
needles with the greatest ens< —a most ingenious contrivance.
* AH good npirtt* come to my JB*vk,n at his Dr. JobnsoiUs Tavern, Bolt Court,
Fleet Street,— where you meet excelWnt company—capita) fare at fair priet-s—delightful si aging --(commences every evening at a quarter to nine,) cigars, billiards,
good beds, and an enticing bill of fare.
Hearing of WILSON'S famous New Footed Boots, called at his depit for
New, Misfitted, and Second-hand Boots and Shoes, 95, & 37, (lolborn Hill, (opposite St. Andrew's Church,] found them of the mow superior description both m
fashion, make, and material, prices from lo». Cwl. to His. —also inspected his very
best boots, which he makes to measure at 21-&--these cannot be surpassed. Thera
is a distinct department for ladies und t. hildreu at 97, which is very convenient-—
Mrs P. intends going
Saturday, I examine Mtss Lrowoon's curious Needlework, Leicester Square—
latelv added other beautiful specimens of her art,—But I intrude—beg pardon—
Yours, &c.~-l'AUL F R Y .

COVENT GARDEN THEATRE.
O N Saturday evening the Comedy of Hubbies of the Day was performed with The White
Cat,
HAYMARKET THEATRE.
A T this Theatre, on Saturday evening, the performances were The
West Indian,
TJte Pretty Girls of Stilberg, and Tom Noddy"J
Secret.
T h e Royal command was on Saturday received at this T h e a t r e , through
the Lord Chamberlain, ( t h e Earl Delaware,) to substitute The
Gamester
for Tfic Lady
of Lyons, for this evening ( M o n d a y , ) her Majesty intending to honour the Theatre with her presence on the occasion, to witness the performance of M r . and Mrs, Charles K can as Mr. and Mrs.
Peverfoy.
The Lady of Lyons will consequently this week be performed
on Wednesday and Friday.
Messrs. T . and J . Ridgway and M r s . Ridgway will appear at the New
Strand Theatre on Monday, May 2nd, in a new Sketch, entitled Les
Trots Tetes de Ptis ! Or, Doings in Bond
Street.
Miss Adelaide Kemble will net ort on an extended provincial tour, immediately after the closing of Covent G a r d e n on the 2 9 t h instant. She
will sing at- a concert at Birmingham on the 6tk of next month.
Philharmonic,—A
rehearsal of the third concert took place on Saturday. T h e symphonies will be Spoor's No 2, in I ) , minor, and Beethoven's No. 7, in A. T h e overtures, the Zavber/Jote,
and Mendelssohn's
Midsummer
Nighfs
Dream.
Molique, ( w h o has just arrived) will play
a solo on the violin ; and M. Parish Alvars, harpist to the Imperial Court
of Vienna, will make his debut in a fantasia on the harp. T h e singers
will be Miss Raittforth, Messrs. Hobhs, and Maehin, we believe. Leader, Mr. T . Cooke | conductor, M r . Potter.
T h e New Musical Fund, which was established it) 1780, is about to
be dissolved. Annuities will be purchased for the present claimants, with
a portion of the funds in hand, and a reserve made for such of the members as may require assistance hereafter.
A new VocntiM
Praham
the Younger.—We find that Mr.C.Braham,
a younger son of the great Braham, has made his debut as a vocalist in
Bos'on, with great and increasing eclat.
T h e following is from a Boston
paper I—
" M> - Praham,
Jun.—This
young gentleman made his first appearance as a singer on Monday evening last. And never have we witnessed
*a successful a debut.
M r . Bran am has a fine manly form, which would
greatly aid him in Opera. His voice is powerful, flexible, and of unequalled richness, and lie evinced not only great musical knowledge, which
indeed we should expect in one who had such a parent for his tutor, but
a degree of taste and feeling, which, added to tin rich melody of his tones,
make him the most delightful vocalist we ever had the pleasure of listening to. If he devotes his rare talents to the profession that nature has so
admirably fitted him for, his career cannot fail tobe a most b r i l l a n t o n e
E, m J, THOMAS, Printers, Russell Court, Br>dges«-t„ Covert Garden.

AND T H E
The Overture and the whole of the Music composed and selected by Mr.R. HUGHES.
T h e Scenery by Mr. GRIEVE, Mr. T. G R I E V E , and Mr. W . G R I E V E .
The Dresses (a happy mixture of the Costumes of every age and nation, sufficiently inaccurate
to satisfy the most unscrupulous) by Miss GLOVJBR and Miss R A Y N E R .
The Mechanical Changes,
Transformations, and Decorations, designed and executed by Mr. W . B R A D W E L L .
The Machinery by Mr. H. SLOMAN.
The Pantomime produced under the direction of Mr. R..HONNER.

Ae GRAND, ROMANTIC. LEGENDARY, BURLESQUE and COMIC
CHRISTMAS PANTOMIME, entitled The

The Overture and the whole of the Music composed and selected by Mr. R. HUGHE 9 .

Th3 Scenery by Mr. GRIEVE, Mr. T. GRIEVE, and Mr. W . GRIEVE.
T h e Dresses by Mr. H E A D , M a d a m e T H O M A S a n d Assistants.
T h e M e c h a n i c a l Changes, Transformations, a n d Decorations, by Mr. W . B R A D W E L L
